Award.AwardTitle: A combined TERS and functional cellular imaging approach to explore receptor function

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264498
Zhou, Anhong


Understanding how the body recognizes and responds to dietary fat is of critical importance to the control of fat intake and treatment of obesity. Our knowledge of the pathways underlying the chemoreception of fatty acids, the prototypical fat stimuli, in fat-responsive tissues has greatly increased in recent years, but the nature of the cognate receptors and their role in this process remains controversial. To explore the role of two receptors (GPR120 and CD36) in fatty acid signaling, the two PIs have developed a novel collaborative approach that encompasses both biophysical and cellular biological approaches to test the hypothesis that CD36 and GPR120 are functionally linked in the initial recognition of fatty acids in chemosensory cells. A combined TERS and calcium imaging system will be developed that for the first time will allow the ability to map the distribution of these receptors at nanoscale resolution and
their function in a single system.

General description:
This proposal will develop novel tools for imaging how particles of fat interact with cells via specific cell-surface receptors. The novel technology will allow to quantify receptors and to monitor how receptors rearrange and co-localize on surfaces of cells. Presence of fatty acids bound to receptors will be determined by a novel tool enabling chemical analysis of the cell surface.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A recent report released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that almost 40 percent of American adults and nearly 20 percent of adolescents are obese. The current epidemic of obesity has been linked to an increase in the incidence of no less than 30 diseases including diabetes, cardiovascular disease, renal disease and cancer. The combined health care costs associated with treating obesity-related diseases could rise by $48 billion to $66 billion per year by 2030.  While there are clearly multiple factors that contribute to dietary-induced obesity, one of the precipitating factors appears to be an increase in the intake of calorically dense, high fat diets. Understanding the mechanisms that contribute to this increase in dietary fat intake would, therefore, seem to be critical to be able to combat obesity on this front.  Despite the importance of understanding how the body recognizes and responds to dietary fat, it is only very recently that we have begun to identify the putative receptors for dietary fatty acids, the prototypical fat stimulus.  There is a clear and distinct relationship between the hedonics of taste and food consumption and the recent identification of taste-responsive pathways for dietary fatty acids are consistent with a potential role of taste in helping guide dietary fat intake.

We have proposed that the two primary putative fatty acid receptors, GPR120 and CD36, work in concert in the initial gustatory transduction events underlying fat taste.  Briefly, CD36 binds the cognate fatty acids and presents these compounds to the fatty acid-activated GPCR (GPR120). However, there are currently precious few data functionally linking these two receptors in fat chemoreception. In past decades, traditional calcium imaging has been utilized widely to elucidate an overall transduction pathway for fatty acids, yet important questions still remain to be answered (Where the fatty acid responsive receptor resides on the cell surface? Whether there exists interactions between these specific receptors in response to fatty acid binding?). This project is aimed to develop receptor-specific nanoprobes and apply to sensitively and specifically detect the sites of two fatty acid-associated receptors at the cell membrane by proposed the non-invasive cell imaging technique (or called enhanced Raman scattering spectroscopy) and cell-based functional assays that would help our better understanding of the role of fatty acids in dietary fat signaling.

We have successfully achieved the three main technical goals as proposed: design, fabrication, and characterization of two receptors (GPR120 and CD36) specific imaging nano-probes; detection of the distribution of these two receptors in model cell system and taste bud cells maintained in tongue tissue; monitoring of fatty acid-receptor interactions on cell surface by using these two receptor probes. The accomplishment of these technical tools and their successful application to an important biological problem will help further our understanding of how the body recognizes dietary fats; information that may prove critical in the battle against dietary-induced obesity.

This project has led to five peer reviewed journal papers and one manuscript is under preparation and will be submitted for publication soon, and eleven presentations in national and professional conferences.

Through this multidisciplinary NSF project, both PIs provides excellent learning resources and opportunities to the trainees involved in this project, including five PhD students (one female minority), two MS students (both female), five undergraduate students (four are female including one female minority student), a local high school student who did his science project in PI’s laboratory starting summer 2018. Almost half of these students are from Biological Engineering, and the other half from Biology. The students learned basic lab skills along with the use of advanced imaging instruments. Two of these participated students are minority female students including one Hispanic undergraduate from Biological Engineering and a Dominican graduate student from Biology. This high school student conducted his science project entitled Raman spectroscopy non-invasive assessment of cytoprotective effect of antioxidant on diesel exhausted particles-induced damage to human lung cells. This project was one of ten high school students science projects selected by State of Utah to compete the 2019 Intel International Science and Engineering Fair, Phoenix, Arizona, May 12-17, 2019.
